> > There is no guarantee that they will run in the order of the test file =
and
> > you should not write your tests in a way that depends on this. You =
should
> > use the setUp and tearDown methods to properly setup each test.
=

> I  know that this is the "pure doctrine". But what do you do, if you
> h=
ave a series of dependent test (some interaction between two systems)
> tha=
t need a defined protocoll and therefor a defined order?

What I do is to m=
ake it one big test. I'll still see if the whole
thing failed or not, and i=
f it fails then the failure message and
the stack trace will help me to tel=
l how far it got. You lose the
usual advantage of running ALL the tests bec=
ause those bits after 
the failing test don't get run, but if we ran those =
bits they wouldn't
be valid tests ANYWAY since they depend on the previous =
test
which failed!

Basically, a single test can be as big as you like, it'=
s just the
unit of testing which is independent of all other tests. USUALLY=

we make very short simple unit tests because we try hard to avoid
this kin=
d of dependence, but your need for dependent tests is not 
unheard of, it's=
 simply to be avoided when possible.

-- Michael Chermside
